Hey Daniel , couldnt reply to u. hope you see this and it help you.

The visible violet light has a wavelength of about 400 nm. Within the visible wavelength spectrum, violet and blue wavelengths are scattered more efficiently than other wavelengths. The sky looks blue, not violet, because our eyes are more sensitive to blue light (the sun also emits more energy as blue light than as violet).
So why isn't the sky violet?

I want to suggest a topic - how close can you get to a rainbow?  A rainbow in the sky, that is.  What do the laws of physics say about how far you must be from the mist in order to view the colors?  I had someone say "I'll bet that rainbow is in the next town over", but can you really place a rainbow in terms of distance?  Where can I make this suggestion?

@joel koh ,in my opinion, your mirror doesn't reflect all light frequency, invisible spectrum of light including ultraviolet and infra-red will pass through your mirror, some of the visible frequency will probably also pass through your mirror, furthermore, the material of mirror also absorb small portion of  light as energy when light impact on it.
In short, mirror doesn't reflect all light, some pass through them, some is absorbed by the material of mirror as energy, therefore light can't be trapped by mirror or any matter, because all matter absorb light, all matter is light, all matter is energy, they transfer from one form to another: E=mc^2 they flow freely and from the form we can see, they become forms we can not see; from the form we can not see, they become the form we can see.    However,  roughly the visible spectrum is 300 nm to 650. so that's 350 nm total. The electromagnetic spectrum goes from 10 Megameters to 1 picometer. So the percentage of the spectrum occupied by visible light is tiny, just 3.5 X 10-7 divided by 10^7 So that's 3.5x10-14% or 0.0000000000000035% Yet, the electromagnetic spectrum goes off as far as you want in both directions - there are electromagnetic waves with wavelengths as small as you want, and others as large as you want. So really the proportion of visible spectrum in light(electromagnetic waves) is 0%

Joel Koh

I believe that the "lowest form of energy" is heat. When light hits a mirror, the mirror is not 100% efficient at reflecting the light, the mirror heat up a tiny bit each time light bounces off, causing less energy in the form of light to be present inside the cube. Since light travels at 299,792,458 ms^-1 (in a vacuum), it bounces off of the mirrors thousands of times every millisecond, that tiny amount of energy converted into heat adds up, and then all the light energy is converted into heat within a fraction of a second. Voila, its dark, almost as soon as the match goes out.
I liked longer videos more

i think Color of the sky is totally dependent on size of suspended particles in the air, which act as a medium allowing light either to pass around them(diffraction) or pass through(transmission) them therefore selectively decide the different depths at which different spectrum of light penetrate into our atmosphere which ultimately decide the proportions of mixture of colors at observing location(earth's surface where we stand). In earth's atmosphere, there are countless suspended particles known as particulates, as a result, they are easy for long frequency light to pass around, including light green, yellow, red, and hard for short frequency light to pass around, including dark green, aqua, blue,purple; instead, short frequency light pass through particles without bending and results in scattering due to massive amount of particles. In conclusion, the light spectrum scattered includes dark green(570nm), aqua(530nm), blue(520nm), purple(430nm), and average mixture of them is (570+530+520+430)/4=512.5nm(dark blue), which is shorter comparing to our sky color( aqua or blue), and the reason obviously is that there are higher portion of dark green(570nm) than purple(430nm) , which is presumably because most purple light is scattered in upper atmosphere due to shorter wavelength whereas green light go further down and get scattered in lower atmosphere, where we observe our visible sky.
at last but not the least, if the particles get larger, the sky color will shift toward long length spectrum,(average mixture: yellow),  and if particles get smaller, the sky color will shift toward short spectrum(average mixture:blueish-purple), and if there's no particles, the sky will not have any color.

You know Joel, I asked a similar question to my physics teacher when I was in high school. What he told me that such a "mirrored" box is not possible because every time the light rays will hit the mirror walls, they will give away some energy to the molecules on the surface. At each reflection, it will lose some energy and eventually the light will die down once it has spent its energy to the mirror wall molecules.

However, if the mirror were perfectly black body (not possible to exist in real) (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_body), we could contain the light in the box.

First, the scattering is called Rayleigh scattering and it does not happen because of any small particle but because of N2 and O2 molecules. When speaking about small particles people might think about dust and smokes which will add another effect: the Mie scattering. But it does not give the sky a blue color as this effect is responsible for brownish cloud above big and polluted cities.

Second, at the end you say that the sunlight becomes yellow but it does not as it becomes red (see sunset and lunar eclipse) as the Rayleigh scattering is a law in 1/λ^4 .

In the end the sky is blue because the Rayleigh scattering scatters blue light so much that only colors with longer wave length may make it to the ground. When near the horizon the Sun is red because the atmosphere has got the time to scatter every other visible color. And when the Sun is high in the sky, the Sun is white/yellowish because if we take into account the atmosphere Rayleigh scattering and the Sun black body radiation, yellow is the dominant color, but not the only one (there is still red), plus the light intensity is so high it saturates and burn our eyes.

This video doesn't explain "why" the sky is blue, but rather then how it's blue. But for a 10 second explanation, it's still good. From what I've heard, how the sky is blue is because when the "white" light passes through the particles in the atmosphere (mostly nitrogen) they react with the matter. Then giving off a wavelength of a light blue in the electro magnetic spectrum.
physics explained in 9.NEIN NEIN NEIN NEIN NEIN....

I don't know if your bonus fact is necessarily accurate. It does not seem to make sense that white light has more of a certain wavelength of light, because to me that sounds like there are less microwaves or gamma rays or others emitted by the sun. Rather, after a quick search on the human eye perception, I found that the human eye is more sensitive to blue-green light, thus creating the peaking.

To test this, try a green laser pointer versus a red laser pointer...and hopefully you're not color blind.

However, I can see why your bonus fact would be correct after passing through the earth's atmosphere because other wavelengths get filtered. Fact check me please?

this needs to be further explained!

Color is a wave length on the electro magnetic spectrum, it is broken up in the atmosphere, because blue has a low frequency the oxygen and nitrogen in the atmosphere bounce it around like a ping pong ball while the other colors just escape. This results in the blue color's wave length being the one that enters your eye, thus blue sky.
